really to bring genomics into clinical practice so genomics is the use of our

how we wanted to assess the value of genomics so we did not go into this saying genomic tests for all and a lot

most radical of them is they put you in hospital they put electrodes all over your brain and they figure out where

change we don't know everything about it yet but once we have your sequence we

right so in our we have a particular cohort of patients who are acutely

every 40 times you do that you find something that you can fix now I get

little kids born with some form of hearing loss parents are told this might

finding the one that is actually the one causing the problems is an incredibly complex process so we thought we'd put
in some technology to support that so the standard workflow for genomic tests
is we've got a patient they take some data some wet lab stuff happens they
prep the sample it goes into a magic sequencing box magic data comes out right the bioinformatic analysis happens
takes all those pieces puts them back together and then we do this thing we call curation and what we mean by that
is figuring out which of those 10 or 20,000 variants is the disease-causing one that curation step is a very manual
step it is a very labor-intensive step it has to be done by somebody who is incredibly brilliant it has to be done
by medical scientists that really really know their stuff it then goes through a multidisciplinary
team review so they bring the person who has done that curation together with the doctor that knows the patient the best
along with a clinical geneticist and they figure out what this result means we get a report and we some returned
some results so that's kind of the general mechanism for how these tests are delivered so to support that we put
in place a system called genomic so it's our shared clinical system for genomics so Melbourne genomics has 10 members and
